repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
feat(ui): builtin ext_cmdline completion popupmenu

Problem:  UIs implementing ext_cmdline/message must also implement
          ext_popupmenu in order to get cmdline completion with
          wildoptions+=pum.
Solution: Allow marking a window as the ext_cmdline window through
          nvim_open_win(), including prompt offset. Anchor the cmdline-
          completion popupmenu to this window.

comment_data.body:
Could keep these private for use with the default ext_cmdline (`_cmdline/_cmdline_offset`) but after testing this seems useful enough to expose.

Not sure if the separate `cmdline` flag is needed. While this is only used for the cmdline completion popupmenu, the `cmdline` flag is a bit redundant and could be merged by treating `cmdlin_offset = 0` as `cmdline = true`. But perhaps we can/should do more with the cmdline window internally where a general flag would make sense.
`:help vim.ui_attach()` doesn't seem to mention the meaning of the return value.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -306,6 +306,92 @@ describe('vim.ui_attach', function()
       },
     })
   end)
+
+  it('ext_cmdline completion popupmenu', function()
+    screen:try_resize(screen._width, 10)
+    screen:add_extra_attr_ids { [100] = { background = Screen.colors.Black } }
+    exec_lua([[
+      vim.o.wildoptions = 'pum'
+      local buf = vim.api.nvim_create_buf(false, true)
+      vim.cmd('call setline(1, range(1, 10))')
+      _G.win = vim.api.nvim_open_win(buf, false, {
+        relative = 'editor',
+        col = 3,
+        row = 3,
+        width = 20,
+        height = 1,
+        style = 'minimal',
+        focusable = false,
+        zindex = 300,
+        cmdline = true,
+        cmdline_offset = -1, -- not inserting "firstc" below
+      })
+      vim.ui_attach(ns, { ext_cmdline = true }, function(event, ...)
+        if event == 'cmdline_show' then
+          local content = select(1, ...)
+          vim.api.nvim_buf_set_lines(buf, -2, -1, false, {content[1][2]})
+          vim.api.nvim_win_set_cursor(_G.win, {1, #content[1][2]})
+          vim.api.nvim__redraw( { win = _G.win, cursor = true, flush = true })
+        end
+        return true

comment_data.body: Yeah, it makes Nvim not send the event to remote UIs. I'm not sure what the reason behind it is. Here is a related issue: #21150.

comment_data.body: Indeed (if I understand correctly): the test case uses remote UI and cannot pass without it. By comparison, at TUI it doesn't matter.

comment_data.body: This test does not test the remote UI state. In this case specifically returning `true` is used to hide the ext_ state from the screen:expect output, the screen class is the remote UI.

@@ -306,6 +306,92 @@ describe('vim.ui_attach', function()
       },

comment_data.body:
If we expose these, they should be options (for reference, the existing `'previewwindow'` option makes a similar kind of decision). Something like a new, global `'cmdlinewin'` or `'cmdpopupwin'` option (or `'...opt'` variant).

Setting a global option as a side-effect of `nvim_open_win` is strange (and ~~introduces a question: how can scripts ask which window is the cmdline-popup window?~~ EDIT: `nvim_win_get_config`).

If it helps unblock this PR, for now let's just not expose these.

Would it make sense to *always* define `cmdline_win`? The default impl would anchor its dimensions to `Columns * Rows`, but that impl would be contained in the default `cmdline_win` handler, so code never needs to check if `cmdline_win` exists:

```suggestion
    m = cmdline_win->w_width_inner * cmdline_win->w_height_inner;
```

I don't know if this is a net gain, so this is suggestion is also a question :)

Still awaiting @bfredl's review, who originally suggested adding this to `nvim_open_win` :) From matrix:

>> I was also wondering if some API to "set" the cmdline window would be better for some internal work Nvim can do. But perhaps documenting that the implementation should move the cursor there to this end is sufficient?

> I think this can be done, but being future-proof for more "roles" being added later. perhaps a field in nvim_win_set_config/win_open

Not clear from this description what the window shows. Is it only for the popup menu? `ext_cmdline` presents the entire cmdline, not only the popup menu.

The name `cmdline` at least is confusing if it doesn't present the entire cmdline.

`nvim_win_set_config` would fit better, since it is essentially window-local properties, which is very similar to window-local options. Though a global option seems to make more sense than a window-local option, since a global option is easier to "query".

`nvim_win_set_config` and `nvim_open_win` share the same `opts` dictionary, so adding it to one implies the other. I'm not sure how a global option would work, do you mean that option would hold the window handle?

> do you mean that option would hold the window handle?

Yes. That seems natural, no?

Or maybe it's weird because creating the popup window is rather coupled to setting the "option", since presumably the window will be short-lived.

What the window contains is entirely up to the cmdline implementation. This just allows the implementation to "mark" the window that is used to display the cmdline as such, to allow Nvim to do some work with it internally.

For now that just means anchoring the completion popupmenu, not sure if anything else could be done. Originally also thought this could be used to redraw and move the cursor to it, but since we can do that with `nvim__redraw` this is no longer necessary.

Yes if it's a global option it would have to be set/unset whenever the window is deleted (which the user could do, at which point the handler would have to create a new window). So unless if we disallow deleting a window marked as such, attaching the flag to the window itself seems to make more sense to me.

There is something to say for symmetry with `'previewwindow'` though, so should probably promote it to an actual window option if @bfredl agrees. This does bring into question the entire `WinConfig` struct.

> This does bring into question the entire `WinConfig` struct.

Let's save that for https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/30453 , out of scope here.
I'd say keep it a `_` field in winconfig for now.

Don't think so; it would have to be a grid not a window (only the default grid relates to `Columns/Rows`). But it's not straightforward to get the inner dimensions from the grid, and we can't query the cmdline row/column from the default grid, so would need ternaries anyways.
comment indent looks wrong
do we need a test for some other offset? maybe using `nvim_win_set_config`?

+      _G.win = vim.api.nvim_open_win(buf, false, {

comment_data.body: "Setting this activates ..."
no need for the quotes, cell width is a well known concept used everywhere already.
Sure, but IIRC I copied this verbatim from nvim_open_win, including the quotes. It's now just an internal comment though so maybe not necessary to copy API text.
Is this just a clean up of the tests to make them more explicit, or is this necessary due to a change of behavior?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -623,8 +623,7 @@ local function test_cmdline(linegrid)
       { 'unplace', '', '', '' },
     }
 
-    command('set wildmode=full')
-    command('set wildmenu')
+    command('set wildmode=full wildmenu wildoptions=pum')

comment_data.body: Includes a behavior change. In this PR ext_popupmenu doesn't (I thought it shouldn't) receive cmdline completion events unless the user sets wildoptions=pum. ext_wildmenu still does regardless of the option.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -623,8 +623,7 @@ local function test_cmdline(linegrid)
       { 'unplace', '', '', '' },
     }
 
-    command('set wildmode=full')
-    command('set wildmenu')
+    command('set wildmode=full wildmenu wildoptions=pum')

comment_data.body:
ext_popupmenu also includes wildmenu (regardless of options):

> - `ext_popupmenu`	Externalize |popupmenu-completion| and
>			'wildmenu'. |ui-popupmenu|

Adding a separate `ext_wildmenu` format  was a mistake and this option is now deprecated.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -623,8 +623,7 @@ local function test_cmdline(linegrid)
       { 'unplace', '', '', '' },
     }
 
-    command('set wildmode=full')
-    command('set wildmenu')
+    command('set wildmode=full wildmenu wildoptions=pum')

comment_data.body: Yes but if the user indicates they don't want a popupmenu for the cmdline through wildoptions, why would we still emit the event? Doesn't that unnecesarily force the ext_popupmenu implementation to check this option value?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -623,8 +623,7 @@ local function test_cmdline(linegrid)
       { 'unplace', '', '', '' },
     }
 
-    command('set wildmode=full')
-    command('set wildmenu')
+    command('set wildmode=full wildmenu wildoptions=pum')

comment_data.body: In the `nvim_open_win` docstring we should mention the flag and mention "EXPERIMENTAL". We don't have a better way of documenting experiemental stuff currently. But not documenting it at all means it could be forgotten and/or lead to confusion in the future.
Behavior changes LGTM, ok w/ @bfredl ?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -623,8 +623,7 @@ local function test_cmdline(linegrid)
       { 'unplace', '', '', '' },
     }
 
-    command('set wildmode=full')
-    command('set wildmenu')
+    command('set wildmode=full wildmenu wildoptions=pum')

comment_data.body:
No, this should not be changed. what `ext_popupmenu` means is forward **the data** related to multiple-choice completion. `ext_popupmenu` does emphatically not refer to the one particular visual style of a menu (which TUI vim has called "the popupmenu" in big singularis) .

Thus whether it is used is irrelevant of `wildoptions+=pum` is set or not, which is a _newer option_ meant to control legacy TUI only. This option toggles between two builtin-UI style of menus, not whether external UI:s can be trusted with doing the rendering or not.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -623,8 +623,7 @@ local function test_cmdline(linegrid)
       { 'unplace', '', '', '' },
     }
 
-    command('set wildmode=full')
-    command('set wildmenu')
+    command('set wildmode=full wildmenu wildoptions=pum')

comment_regular_data.body:
LGTM after comments are resolved, plus updated "Problem" mentioning something like:

> UIs implementing ext_cmdline/message must also implement ext_popupmenu just to get a cmdline completion popup.
I started using this and haven't noticed any special issues for now.
Resolving the conflict would make local merging easier.

labels.description: UI extensibility, events, protocol, externalized UI
labels.name: ui-extensibility

title: feat(ui): builtin ext_cmdline completion popupmenu
